content.raw: This is still a work in progress.  SystemInternal expects a `unique_ptr`, but I believe that the loader has to retain a copy of the `shared_ptr`
content.html: This is still a work in progress. SystemInternal expects a unique_ptr, but I believe that the loader has to retain a copy of the shared_ptr

content.raw: Do `Physics` and `WorldStatistics` need to be in the config file as well?
content.html: Do Physics and WorldStatistics need to be in the config file as well?

content.raw: Rephrasing: can `Physics` and `WorldStatistics` be removed from the config file?
content.html: Rephrasing: can Physics and WorldStatistics be removed from the config file?

content.raw:
The config file just is a list of available plugins along with how to load them.  This set is what is actually created ona a per-world basis.  I would expect that we would have a method of attaching these to an sdf::World instance at some point.  
  
Each world in this case could get a different set of systems, if you needed to selectively enable/disable systems, or load say a client on one world and a server on another.
content.html:
The config file just is a list of available plugins along with how to load them. This set is what is actually created ona a per-world basis. I would expect that we would have a method of attaching these to an sdf::World instance at some point.

Each world in this case could get a different set of systems, if you needed to selectively enable/disable systems, or load say a client on one world and a server on another.

content.raw: Are we keeping the config in a file because we expect users to override it with their own configuration? What happens if they remove `Physics` from the file? I'd expect physics not to be loaded in that case. I guess I don't understand why we need `defaultSystems` if we can get the list of systems to be loaded from the config file.
content.html: Are we keeping the config in a file because we expect users to override it with their own configuration? What happens if they remove Physics from the file? I'd expect physics not to be loaded in that case. I guess I don't understand why we need defaultSystems if we can get the list of systems to be loaded from the config file.

content.raw: defaultSystems in this case is a placeholder.  In the future, I imagine that we’ll want to load those systems from the sdf file.   The config file in this case is also an exhaustive list \(obviously we don’t have many systems at the moment\), so I don’t know if you would want to attach every system in that config file to every world?
content.html: defaultSystems in this case is a placeholder. In the future, I imagine that we’ll want to load those systems from the sdf file. The config file in this case is also an exhaustive list (obviously we don’t have many systems at the moment), so I don’t know if you would want to attach every system in that config file to every world?

content.raw:
I'm trying to think of the use-cases. Do you agree we want the following features and is there anything else you were thinking of supporting in the near future?

* Ign-gazebo loads a few plugins by default
* User can choose at load time to turn off selected default plugins
* User can choose at load time to load extra custom plugins built outside of ign-gazebo
* (future) user can load / unload plugins at runtime
content.html:
I'm trying to think of the use-cases. Do you agree we want the following features and is there anything else you were thinking of supporting in the near future?

  • Ign-gazebo loads a few plugins by default
  • User can choose at load time to turn off selected default plugins
  • User can choose at load time to load extra custom plugins built outside of ign-gazebo
  • (future) user can load / unload plugins at runtime

content.raw:
Yes, this looks correct, wit the only clarification being that the plugin loading and system instantiation is deferred to the actual creation of the SimulationRunner.

So it may be better to state:

* Ign-gazebo has a list of default plugins
* User can modify that list to remove plugins
* User can modify the list to add additional custom plugins

At which point this list is used to instantiate systems and populate them in the runner.
content.html:
Yes, this looks correct, wit the only clarification being that the plugin loading and system instantiation is deferred to the actual creation of the SimulationRunner.

So it may be better to state:

  • Ign-gazebo has a list of default plugins
  • User can modify that list to remove plugins
  • User can modify the list to add additional custom plugins

At which point this list is used to instantiate systems and populate them in the runner.

content.raw:
So to use a custom plugin, a user needs to:

1. Add the plugin library to a path known by ign-gazebo (such as a known directory or one given by an env var)
1. Add the plugin to `systems.config` file
1. Refer to the plugin in the `custom.world` file

It looks to me like we could reduce to 2 steps if we embedded all the info needed to load a custom plugin to the world file.

And to allow them to remove default plugins, we need to remove the hardcoded list from the code.

(note that I'm not saying we need to address all this in this PR, but I just wanted to make sure we're on the same page)
content.html:
So to use a custom plugin, a user needs to:

  1. Add the plugin library to a path known by ign-gazebo (such as a known directory or one given by an env var)
  2. Add the plugin to systems.config file
  3. Refer to the plugin in the custom.world file

It looks to me like we could reduce to 2 steps if we embedded all the info needed to load a custom plugin to the world file.

And to allow them to remove default plugins, we need to remove the hardcoded list from the code.

(note that I'm not saying we need to address all this in this PR, but I just wanted to make sure we're on the same page)

content.raw: I do agree that this part can be reworked, though.
content.html: I do agree that this part can be reworked, though.

content.raw:
Is the system manager in the server level as opposed to the simulation runner level because we want to have systems that act across worlds?

In that case, we may need to move the `EntityComponentManager` to a higher level too, to avoid entity collisions. Or are we planning on having an extra way of identifying the entities, such as a world namespace?
content.html:
Is the system manager in the server level as opposed to the simulation runner level because we want to have systems that act across worlds?

In that case, we may need to move the EntityComponentManager to a higher level too, to avoid entity collisions. Or are we planning on having an extra way of identifying the entities, such as a world namespace?

content.raw: This isn’t to have systems that act across worlds, rather it is to control the loading/unloading of shared libraries at the executable level, rather than on a per-world level.  The ServerManager would return System instances that can be used on a per-world basis.
content.html: This isn’t to have systems that act across worlds, rather it is to control the loading/unloading of shared libraries at the executable level, rather than on a per-world level. The ServerManager would return System instances that can be used on a per-world basis.

content.raw: I see, so the system manager would hold multiple instances of the same system side-by-side, right? Makes sense to me.
content.html: I see, so the system manager would hold multiple instances of the same system side-by-side, right? Makes sense to me.

content.raw: Could this be done outside `SimulationRunner` so only the final product is passed in the constructor (i.e. `systemPlugin`s)? (or maybe there are future plans here which justify the current approach?)
content.html: Could this be done outside SimulationRunner so only the final product is passed in the constructor (i.e. systemPlugins)? (or maybe there are future plans here which justify the current approach?)

content.raw:
It certainly can, the only reason it’s happening here is that’s where the System instances were being constructed before.   
  
You could potentially act on information coming from the sdf::World in order to change how systems are instantiated, but I think you could do that just as easily outside as inside.
content.html:
It certainly can, the only reason it’s happening here is that’s where the System instances were being constructed before.

You could potentially act on information coming from the sdf::World in order to change how systems are instantiated, but I think you could do that just as easily outside as inside.

content.raw: Shouldn't we check if `systemPlugin` is a nullptr before adding it the list?
content.html: Shouldn't we check if systemPlugin is a nullptr before adding it the list?

content.raw: Consider naming `_systems` to `_systemAliases` to make it clear that it’s not the class name.
content.html: Consider naming _systems to _systemAliases to make it clear that it’s not the class name.

content.raw:
Not sure if you already have plans for this, but it should be totally doable within the current SDF spec if we use `name` as `alias`, for example:

~~~
<world name="world1">
  <plugin
    name="MyCoolSystem" 
    filename"libMyCoolSystem.so" 
    classname="my::cool::System" 
    type=""ignition::gazebo::System"
  />
</world>
~~~
content.html:
Not sure if you already have plans for this, but it should be totally doable within the current SDF spec if we use name as alias, for example:

<world name="world1">
  <plugin
    name="MyCoolSystem" 
    filename"libMyCoolSystem.so" 
    classname="my::cool::System" 
    type=""ignition::gazebo::System"
  />
</world>

content.raw: Some style and other small suggestions on pull request #31. Feel free to merge what makes sense to you. We talked offline, but [here](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code&cat=development#Style)'s a style reference as context for others. It would be awesome if these details were eventually caught by a script, but so far we've been human-checking them...
